name: Clords
controls: Mouse to click on word parts.
description: Clords is a word game with crossword-like hints and a bank of word-parts that can be used to build up solutions to the hints. Complete all of the levels to win the game. The game is a knock-off of the app "7 Little Words".
remarks: Clords was the first major graphical program I made on my own. The creative control Java Swing provided in 2011 inspired me to start creating the games I always wanted to play as kid.

name: Evolution
controls: Mouse to draw elements, left/right arrow keys to change elements, up/down arrow keys to change drawing size.
description: Evolution is a simulation game to explore interactions between different elements. Place water, oil, fire, lava, plant, and more. Based on the popular genre of online element simulations like Powder Game and Powder Toy.
remarks: My first time playing one of these element simulation games was on a friend's jail-broken iPod Touch in middle school. There was something so exciting about touching a screen with your finger and seeing particle effects come to lift. While that game had only a few elements, I later found the Dan-Ball Powder Game on which I wasted countless hours growing trees and watching ants build complex nests.

name: Vector
controls: Mouse to select marble trajectories, keyboard to type.
description: Vector is a glorified game of marbles. It's a multiplayer game with the ability to chat with other online players and change the color of your character. You can challenge another player to a game and the goal is to knock the other player's marbles off the stage. The game was inspired by the multiplayer Android game Cestos.
remarks: Vector was the final project of my data structures clas in high school. It was a collaboration with my friend Jason Zhao and we built the game over a few weeks using Java Sockets.

name: Three Farmer
description: Three Farmer is a knock-off of the Android and iPhone app Triple Town. The goal is to place items on a grid so that similar items combine and your town grows without overcrowding.

name: Color Match
controls: Click to select a tile, click on an empty space to place a selected tile.
description: Color Match is a puzzle game where the goal is to move tiles from one side of the board to the other so that the edge colors of each tile match those of the adjacent tiles.
remarks: This game was based off of an old Android app, but I can't find it on the Google Play store anymore.

name: Sketcher
controls: F = up, D = down, J = left, K = right, delete = shake/erase, shift = undo, click on menu to save and open past sketches.
description: Sketcher is a knock-off of the classic kids' toy Etch A Sketch.

name: Dot Drawings
controls: Move mouse to oncover the pictures, spacebar to start a new picture.
description: Dot drawings is a toy program where you drag your mouse over the screen to uncover a picture. It was done in collaboration with Robert Gerdisch who helped with the color averaging algorithm.
remarks: This is actually based on some online widget that I have not been able to dig up.

name: Check My Code
description: Check My Code was a website I built when first learning web-development. I imagined an environment where students could collaborate on programming homework, teachers could efficiently grade assignments, and learning resources would be available to students that wanted to go above and beyond. While it never made it into production, it provides a look back to a time when Ruby and PHP still reigned over fledgling JavaScript frameworks.

name: Armada
controls: Arrow keys for player 1, W/A/S/D keys for player 2.
description: Armada is a two player skill game where you use the keyboard to steer your boat toward gold coins. The player who collects the most gold coins wins. Armada is a knock-off of the Dubloon Disaster game on Neopets.
remarks: When starting to create Armada I realized I had some good experience creating games on my own, but I needed to work on being more collaborative. I asked my friend Mattie Shepard, a very talented designer, to help me create a better visual experience for my game. She came up with some graphical assets that I could import into the game. The final product had a different feel from anything I had worked on before and it got me excited about the novel results that can come from putting two heads together.

name: Base
description: Base is a web page for converting numbers between different bases. I found that most online converters only converted between common bases like 2, 10, and 16. This web project offered conversion between many bases, all the way up to base 36 to encode/decode any English letters and numbers.

name: Park Tudor Chemical Database
description: The Park Tudor Chemical Database (PTCD) was an end of year project I worked on with my high school classmates Jason Zhao and Michael Xu. We worked with the science department to clarify requirements and design a new system to keep track of chemicals stored for use in chemistry and biology classes. We came up with an administrator website for inventory management, a QR code labeling system for chemical containers, and a web app to allow teachers to check out chemicals with their QR enabled smart phones. Upon checking out a chemical, a teacher would receive an email with official chemical safety information.

name: Tower of Hanoi
controls: Left/right arrow keys to move pointer, space to pick up/put down discs, R key to reset, number keys to change the number of discs, equals key to check high scores.
description: Tower of Hanoi is a mathematical puzzle game. By moving one disc at a time, the goal is to move all discs from the left to the right stack without placing a larger disc on a smaller one. This implementation of the game adds a timer, making the goal a short solving time rather than a small number of moves.
remarks: My high school data structures class assigned homework to write a Tower of Hanoi solver. However, turning a graphical game into a command-line solver didn't feel right. I created this game at a time when I started to feel confident in my ability to create a visually appealing game given enough time.

name: Can You Count
description: Can You Count is a simple and silly game I created for the Ludum Dare game jam 2013. The goal is to count to ten seconds as precisely as possible. The closer you get, the higher your score.
remarks: I have never been very good at just sitting down and hacking on a project on-demand, but an incredible game developer friend of mine asked me to join him for Ludum Dare, so I created this little toy in a few hours. My goal was to create something that looked good but was definitely achievable in a short amount of time. The concept is ridiculously simple, but I'm still proud of how it turned out in such a short amount of time.

name: Scheduler HD
description: Scheduler HD was a website I created with my friend Jason Zhao during high school. We saw our peers posting their class schedules on Facebook and saw an opportunity to help students coordinate their schedules more effectively. We worked to make the process of looking up friends easy, but also private and secure. Days after launching, school administrators brought the effort to a halt with concerns that students with perfect knowledge of their classmates' schedules would become a huge headache for the school scheduling team.

name: Tiles
controls: Arrow keys to move around, spacebar to reset the level.
description: Tiles is a puzzle game where the aim is to move a player around a board to touch every tile exactly once. There are ten levels that get progressively harder. The game is roughly based on the Miniclip game Bloxors where a block will fall through the floor if it rolls over the same area twice.

name: Blocks
controls: Arrow keys to move blocks, space to drop a block.
description: Blocks is a knock-off of the classic falling blocks game Tetris.

name: Flock
description: Flock was one of my early attempts at graphical and physical simulations. The program simulates the flight of flocking birds using something similar to the popular Boids algorithm.

name: Unhinged
controls: Click on a door to enter it. Find the room indicated on the home screen to win the game.
description: Unhinged is a memory game. The goal is to find your way out of a haunted house. Keep track of which rooms you've visited and try not to get lost.
A knock-off of the 2048 puzzle game by Gabriele Cirulli.
remarks: One major downside of my implementation is the lack of animations which makes playing this knock-off much less fun than the original.

name: Viewer
controls: Arrow keys to move around, W/A/S/D keys to rotate the camera, escape key to exit the simulation.
description: Viewer is simple implementation of a 3D world with objects rendered to the screen as sets of triangles.
remarks: Viewer was the first 3D program I created from scratch. At this point I still had very little experience working with any code other than my own and so if I wanted 3D graphics I would have to create it myself. I didn't know that much vector math, let alone the quaternions needed to do 3D rotation correctly. Nevertheless, the project turned out alright.

name: Directed
controls: Click to create a node, drag between two nodes to connect them, right click a node to delete it.
description: Directed is a simulation for building force directed graphs.

name: Song Search
description: Song Search was the final project of my Data Structures course in college. The assignment was to design an implement a method of preprocessing a large database of song lyrics in order to efficiently query for songs based on their lyrics.

name: Sweyp
controls: Mouse dragging to select a word, R key to start a new game.
description: Sweyp is a knock-off of the classic game Boggle where you construct words by connecting chains of adjacent letters from a 4x4 array.
remarks: I started working on this game when my college roommate was assigned a Boggle solver for his intro to Computer Science course. I thought it could be a good chance for me to improve upon my previous graphical projects and include animations to make the game more exciting. I had previously struggled to decouple controller and view layers in games and this was the first project where I discovered those design patterns for myself.

name: Interval Tree
description: A Swift implementation of interval trees using balanced AVL trees.

name: LCS
description: A Swift implementation of longest common subsequence.

name: Jumbo Meal
description: Jumbo Meal was a website I created at the end of my sophomore year in college. As I prepared to move off campus and leave my dining plan behind, I realized that students often spent more on meal plans than they needed to. Selecting a smaller meal plan and then paying for some meals in cash (JumboCash) could save you hundreds of dollars per semester. This little calculator told you the meal schedule you should follow to save the most money based on your meal preferences.

name: Convolutional Mammogram Analysis
description: "Convolutional Mammogram Analysis" was my Intro to Machine Learning course final project working with Henry Zhou and Yuki Zaninovich. The project was an paper on training a deep learning model to detect tumors.

name: Cheso
description: Cheso (pronounced CHAY-so) is an esoteric programming language that is a knock-off of BrainFuck.
remarks: After I completed my systems programming class in college (most projects were in C) I realized I was going to quickly lose my ability to program in C. I started this project as an excuse to write some C code outside the classroom, something I didn't expect to ever do again.

name: Chans
description: Chans is a project I completed for my computational geometry course in college. It is a visualization of Timothy Chan's algorithm for computing the convex hull of a point set. This project gives a walkthrough of the algorithm to explain its implementation and complexity.

name: Zhed Solver
description: Zhed is a puzzle app for iPhone and Android. The goal, roughly, is to extend bridges in the correct order and direction to reach a goal location. This program is a solver for Zhed levels.
remarks: One thing I love about Zhed is how the levels are laid out. Each level gets just slightly harder and every few levels you will be guided to a new insight that helps you solve all levels more efficiently. The game gives you a feeling of discovery that is rare to find in a game with such a simple interface.

name: Half Plane
description: Half Plane is a project I completed for my advanced algorithms course in college. It is a visualization of the half-plane range reporting algorithm with fractional cascading. This project gives a walkthrough of the algorithm to explain its implementation and complexity.

name: Combust
description: Combust was my first project for my college web visualization course.

name: Split Plot
description: Split Plot was a web project I created with the intent to help track and cross country coaches keep track of workout results. My college coaches would print out blank spreadsheets and painstakingly fill out rows and columns with athlete names and split times. Split Plot attempted to automate away some of that pain by providing a consistent template for entering workout descriptions. That template would then be converted into a standard form that could be manually filled in away from the computer during workouts.

name: CompRank
description: CompRank is a web interface for ranking items within some arbitrary category by comparing them. A user is presented with two items to compare and the result of that comparison is then used to update rankings for the whole category.

name: TSA
description: TSA: The Stealing Administration was a final project for my college visualization class in collaboration with Zach Kirsch. We build a web visualization tool that allowed users to explore which airports receive the most reports of theft. Since the advent of strict American airport security post 2001, theft among TSA agents has been the subject of multiple news stories. We built the visualization around the idea that people care most about airports they visit often. We make it easy to explore all claims filed to the TSA under different categories like electronics, clothing, or jewelry and see how often those claims are accepted.

name: TUTF Trends
description: TUTF trends is a website that pulls data from the TFRRS college track and field results reporting website. The results are then visualized per-athlete and per-event to show trends in athlete performance over time.

name: PCI
description: The Perturbational Complexity Index is a promising measure of awareness and perhaps consciousness. This project is a visualization of the data pulled from the research paper "Stratification of Unresponsive Patients by an Independently Validated Index of Brain Complexity" (Casarotto et al. 2016).

name: MIU
description: MIU is a toy theorem prover based on a puzzle in the book Gödel, Escher, Bach: An Eternal Golden Braid.

name: SemiGenre
description: SemiGenre is a program that pulls data from SoundCloud and iTunes libraries to learn the landscape of music. It provides a more fine-grained description of style or genre.

name: Flicker
description: Flicker is a Raspberry Pi project used to continuously monitor the environment of a room. It includes utilities for monitoring new data streams and a dashboard for visualizing unexpected changes.
remarks: The light fixture in my kitchen would go off unexpectedly so I decided to start tracking the light levels for patterns. It turns out that the lights were mounted to an induction plate that would shut off after being on for a while.

name: Dependy
description: Dependy is a utility for visualizing the modules of a python library. The tool helps developers reason about the dependencies in their programs in order to design more modular and robust systems.

name: DirSum
description: Summarize a directory recursively by file size. This tool can be used to quickly search a drive for large files taking up too much space.

name: Kami Sovler
description: Kami is a puzzle app for iPhone and Android. It is in a category of flood-fill games where the goal is to update colors of areas on the screen until all areas are of the same color. This program is a solver for Kami levels.
remarks: The thing I find so fascinating about the Kami game is that unlike some other puzzle games, it's relatively easy to solve Kami levels, however programming a computer to solve Kami levels has been quite hard, a great example of Moravec's paradox. The difficulty of programming the human intuition is something I find extremely compelling.

name: TinyTable
description: Empirical tool to find the best file format for caching a particular dataset. Run on a CSV file to compress it.

name: Generals SDK
description: The Generals SDK is a Python API for analyzing the results of the online game generals.io. Generals.io is a multiplayer game with all results open to the world. This makes scraping game data extremely easy. This API supports ranking players with ELO and trueRank algorithms.

name: On Move
description: A simple web page with multiplayer support. When the server is running, users can open the site and control a character and see other users' characters move in real-time.
remarks: This project uses Three.js for 3D graphics and Socket.IO for real-time multiplayer support.

name: Triple Town
description: Triple Town is a knock-off of the Android and iPhone app Triple Town. The goal is to place items on a grid so that similar items combine and your town grows without overcrowding.

name: Spike
description: Spike is a simple implementation of a spiking neural network (SNN), designed to more closely model biological neural networks than artificial neural networks (ANNs).

name: Robby
description: Robby is a small project that uses a genetic algorithm to teach a robot (named Robby) to pick up trash in a cluttered room.

name: jsonvl
description: jsonvl is a command line tool and python module that validates JSON based on typed schemas.

name: Big Life
description: Web visualization of Conway's Game of Life. Uses a sparse cell representation to make computing larger patterns more efficient.

name: hlucb
description: A Python implementation of the Hamming-LUCB algorithm from the paper "Approximate ranking from pairwise comparisons".

name: Orbit
description: A dynamic musical simulation of planets orbiting a star.

name: Contraction
description: This project is a solver for a mobile puzzle game called Kami. Levels from Kami are converted from images to graphs and solved by a series of graph contractions. A graph neural network is trained to predict the number of contractions needed to solve a level. The network is used as a search heuristic for the solver.

name: Ants
description: Web visualization of ants foraging. Ants drop one type of pheromone when leaving the nest and another when they have found food. By using pheromone density as a navigation heuristic a colony of ants can quickly forage large clusters of food.

name: Chladni
description: Web visualization of Chladni figures. A vibrating surface is simulated as a 2D standing wave. Sand particles are added which bounce around, their magnitude of movement proportional to the surface's wave magnitude. Regions on the surface with no movement correspond to nodes of the wave and sand tends to pool in these regions.

name: Decidio
description: Little web tool to help you make hard decisions. Fill out your options and the criteria you care about and decidio will help you reason about the best choice.

name: bfprt
description: Fast median finding with the median of medians selection algorithm, also known as BFPRT - named after the authors of Blum et al. (1973).

name: Quad
description: Boids flocking simulation with an optional quadtree visualization.

name: Cado
description: Cado is a notebook IDE with a focus on reactivity. By explicitly defining cell dependencies you get benefits that other notebook IDEs like Jupyter can't provide.

name: EngineRoom
description: Hub for boathouse and rowing logistics. A web app to enable members of rowing boathouses to quickly generate lineups for practices.
